string.text: Ulikshorn lies beside the Jumne River as it cuts through the hills known as the Iltanhindrun, named because they posed a barrier to mountain tribes just across the frontiers. Those peoples were pushed farther south and absorbed into the Khuzait confederacy, leaving a considerable land trafficked only by nomadic herdsmen and raiders. The region is rich in wheat, barley and other grains.

Rovalatys, in the mountains of the Ebor Peninsula, was never fully an imperial town. Nordic migrants, drawn to the region by rumors of riches to be made prospecting for silver or hunting for furs, long outnumbered Calradians even before the Vlandian invasion. The Vlandians too recognized its potential, and despite its harsh winters this land is among the more populous regions of the kingdom, with bountiful fields in the valleys of the mountains feeding the constant flow of settlers from the south drawn here by their hunger for wealth.

Chornad in the Neurval Valley, beneath the Biscan Hills. The villagers of this region, like many in the central Vlandian kingdom, specializing in raising pigs on the plentiful acorns that fall from the region's oak trees.
Tor Melina lies on a flank of the Morcomb, a valley at the northwestern edge of the Battanian realm. The slopes, well-drained and exposed to the sun, produce a fine crop of wheat.
Hanekhy sits atop a northern spur of the Akkan Hills. Each day, the villagers climb down winding paths to tend their wheatfields in the plains below.

Hakarshus was the first settlement on the northern coast of Beinland. Its founder, Hakar, harbored a resentment towards authority that was fierce even by local standards. His descendants have become walrus hunters and whalers, venturing to the far north, away from kings and jarls and taxes, in search of their quarry.
Varagos sits on the Aris River, which flows into the deep pool known as the Ophthys. Landowners here have planted mulberry bushes on the warm hillsides, on which they cultivate silkworms.
Ostrif sits on a plateau on the eastern end of the Nordvyg coast. The villagers raise cattle on the grassy pastures above the sea-cliffs.

Hertogea lies in the shadow of Mount Erithrys. Villagers grow olives on the slopes leading up the mountain. This region is home to a number of hot springs as well as caves that smell of the vapors of the earth. One of them - it is known not which - was home to a Palaic oracle who delivered a series of prophecies about the rise and eventual fall of the Empire. Imperial scholars with a mystical bent hotly debate which of the cryptic verses are authentic, and which ones are later inventions.

The tale of Sarpea of Onira is one of the epic poems of the eastern frontier. Like many, it seems written to justify the Empire's conquest. Sarpea, a senator's daughter, was seized by a Palaic chieftain and carried to his citadel here. When the imperial armies appeared before its walls years later to rescue her, she begged them to retreat for the sake of her infant son, whom her fearsome husband had threatened to hurl from the walls instead of allowing him to be captured and raised by his mother's people. The legions withdrew, so the story says, but the boy grew into a warrior who joined the Empire and slew his father. The town is now the main trading center for the herders and miners of the eastern Tanaetic plain.

Gauksdal sits on the middle reaches of the Jumne, the river that the Khuzaits call the Karakaz. This stretch of valley is named in commemoration of Gauk, a local homesteader, who escaped a Khuzait ambush by swimming across the river in spring when it was choked with floating ice. Villagers now plant flax by the river's weedy shallows.

The clifftop village of Skarthness is known for its intrepid mariners. While most of their neighbors are content to fish nearby banks, Skarthnessers voyage seasonally to the far north of Beinland on walrus hunts, bringing back valuable ivory.

Pen Cannoc sits on a promontory overlooking the Etircomb pass as it plunges from the Uchalion plateau into the Vlandian lowlands. Legends speak of the water-nymphs who live in springs that form in the cliffside, luring travellers and invaders to their deaths, except on those rare occasions when they fall in love with a hero and grant him victory and blessings. Certainly the people of this region have learned respect for the perils of the Etircomb, where a small misstep on slippery stone can cast one off a precipice into the gorge below.

Vinela on the landward side of the Epiric Hills, facing the Gavys River. Early morning sea-mists that come up the Gavys valley from the Perassic, together with the hot sun of midday, allow the growing of wine grapes.

Erzenur sits alongside the east branch of the Tiagys River. It is known in the local dialect as the Kizil Teyagh from the strong reddish tint in the iron-rich sediments borne in its currents. Villagers will often divert the waters to wash away soil and expose new seams of ore.
Nifdal is named for the dense mists that rise in the morning from the nearby Jumne river. The villagers here raise shaggy-haired cattle bred to withstand the bitter winters.

Myzea gives its name to the Myzead, the mountainous highlands of the eastern Empire. This region is the old stomping grounds of the senator Litos, who brought the Palaic tribes here into the Empire relatively peacefully by offering them protection against raiders from the steppes. When he fell afoul of his rivals in the Senate, however, he tried to organize them into a rival 'barbarian' republic modelled on the ancient Calradian version. The empire snuffed it out, but the people here, now thoroughly Calradicized, still harbor an attachment to the old republican system and its partisans.
Ataconia sits near the headwaters of the Aris river in the piedmont of the Dryatic Mountains. The hills, rich with oak trees, are ideal for the raising of acorn-eating swine.
Korsyas sits on the bay that the Sturgians call the Battanian Sea. Villagers here specialize in hunting blackfish, minke and other smaller whales that breed here in the protected waters.

Dorstrand overlooks a grim gravel beach in the western end of the Nordvyg. Villagers earn their living by fishing cod, char and other arctic fish, including a variety of deepwater sharks whose flesh must be fermented before it is eaten.

Meroc overlooks a cove in the Biscan Coast. Like many villages in this region, its inhabitants fish nearby banks for mullet and cod for their day-to-day meals, while its bolder seafarers go much further into the western ocean to hunt more lucrative quarry, in particular whales.

Varnovapol, which sits beneath the Chertyg Mountains on the crystal waters of Lake Laconis, has the dubious honor of being perhaps the most-often conquered city in Calradia. Originally it was a colony of the Empire, infamous as a place of exile for dissident senators, before it was seized by Nords as a base to expand their influence into the Sturgian fur trade. It was taken by the Alkit tribe from the eastern steppe and briefly served as the capital of a small khanate, before finally falling to the fierce Ormidoving clan.

The villagers of Holarsver fish the eastern Byalic Sea, where the runoff from the streams creates a brackish mix of saltwater and fresh. Here the catch consists of salmon, sea-trout and bottom-dwelling fish like flounder, caught in wicker traps.

The seafaring village of Tharklif lies at the foot of a cliff overlooking the Byalic Sea. The inhabitants fish local stocks of char and cod, but are most known for their long-ranging voyages in pursuit of right whales and bowheads which migrate through these waters.

The villagers of Kvol include the descendants of refugees and malcontents from across Calradia, seeking isolation in the cold northern forests. They grow barley for sustenance, but many far afield for seasonal work. Some join Nords and others on their walrus hunts in the far north.

Carphenion lies in the rolling hills east of Mount Erithrys. On summer nights the hills above the village are dotted with the fires of cattle herders, taking their animals to graze on the upland pastures.

Husn Fulq, Fulq's citadel, stands at the landward side of the Jabal al-Kals, the hills of bitterness, that divide the Aserai lands from the Empire. Fulq, also known as Phalcos, was a dark-faced mercenary chieftain who came from lands far to the south. He founded a fortress here and then parlayed its strategic location into a fortune, taking bribes from the Empire and then from the Aserai to switch sides. After 20 years of playing both sides back and forth he sailed home in a ship laden with gold, but many clans of the Aserai proudly claim descent from him, and the 'Tricks of Fulq' are a staple of many a bazaar storyteller's repetoire.

Makeb sits on the northern tip of Lake Tanaesis, Tanaz in the steppe tongue. This city has long been ruled by petty khans and shahs, who collect tolls from traders forced to haul their boats around the rapids. The last of those rulers was beheaded by Urkhun himself after he refused a demand of tribute, after which the ruling family of the Khuzaits seized this town for themselves.

Thralathorp was settled by fugitives and runaways from various estates in the Jumne valley. It lies far to the east of the main Nord settlements, on the edge of the steppe. Isolation, freezing winters and frequent Khuzait raids ensure that there are few who would bother disputing their title. The people here make what money they can scraping clay from the bottom of the river in the months when the land is not frozen solid.

Kjarved lies in the inland valleys of the western Nordvyg. Villagers tell stories of their famously foul-tempered and miserly ancestor Kjar, who came inland from the sea to escape a blood feud. For 60 years he mined salt from nearby deposits and accumulated a fabulous trove of wealth, all of which was a huge surprise to his dozens of children and grandchildren when they entered his modest farmhouse after his death to claim their inheritance.

Grud was a thegn of the jarl of Hargard who established an outpost east of the Jumne River, which takes its name from the mysterious burial pits from some bygone people that lined its banks. The village named after him now herds sheep that range far out over the cold steppe to the east.

Fimbulgard was named for the beach-side shacks used to dry herring, the staple food of its seafaring inhabitants. The wealth of the village, however, comes from the seasonal voyages along the northern coasts in search of whales and their oil.

Zestea sits overlooking the Sethys River as it flows into the Perassic Sea. The conjoining of the waters makes for rich fishing grounds, for the shad and sardines who thrive in the brackish estuary waters as well as the tuna who come to eat them.
Hongard sits in the warm wooded lands near the meandering Trand River. This region, rich in wheat and once the heartland of the Empire, is now the center of the Vlandian kingdom.
Urunjan sits near the eastern edge of the Devseg plateau, at the foot of the Sulan Dag mountains. Villagers raise cattle here that are bred to withstand both the hot summers and freezing winters.

Tyal sits atop a high valley that climbs Mount Iltan, a craggy peak in eastern Calradia named for a god of the steppe peoples. This region has long stood aloof from the power struggles of the other Sturgian principalities. Its people are known as wanderers, traders, horse breeders and fur-trappers. The local aristocracy has occasionally exchanged princesses with the steppe tribes to the east to firm up a truce or a trade pact, and proudly includes the names of several great khans on their list of ancestors.
The village of Esme and its surrounding hamlets lie on the landward side of the Akkan Hills on the Devseg plateau, prime grazing lands for the horses of the Khuzaits and their confederates.

Vagnafit lies in a basin under the hills known as the Kjolfjallen, from their resemblance to the keel of a ship. The once boggy depression was drained under the orders of King Volbjorn, and the land distributed to some of the veterans who helped him gain power to grow wheat for Thronderlag and other towns.

Gamardan sits at a key gap in the Epiric Hills, on the route between Charas and the imperial cities of the Aminys valley. The wines of this region are unusually sweet and strong, and valued throughout the Empire.
Ransam lies in the southern plains of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, specialize in the rearing of horses.

Svinstak lies inland of the Nordvyg coast, separated from the sea by a row of sharp-ridged hills. Stands of old-growth oak and other trees are still common here, providing the north with much of the timber for its ships.

Hoeksten is named after a mysterious monolith found in the fields here by wandering herdsmen, subsequently ordered dug up by the local jarl and used in the foundations of Ykerslund Castle. He also ordered a village built on the auspicious site to settle refugees who had fled from the wars of Nord unification on the coast, and provided them with herds of cattle.

Dagby lies in the heights above Gretysfjord. Residents of the town harvest the great oaks on the slopes for the town's shipbuilding industry. On the summer solstice, village youths race by riding the logs as they slide down the hill, risking mangled limbs or broken backs for a chance at glory.

The former Nord colony of Varcheg sits on a windswept bluff at the base of the Kachyar Peninsula in what was once Battanian land. The jarl who founded this outpost, hoping to trade with the interior, pledged himself in fealty to the Battanian High King Dernmachad, but then proceeded to dabble in Battanian politics. Annoyed, Dernmachad hired a Sturgian army to crush his unreliable new vassal. The Sturgians complied and routed the Nords, but then demanded the newly captured town as their payment. They called the town 'Varcheg,' a corruption of the Nordic term for 'oathsworn companion,' to mock both rivals whose quarreling had handed them their prize.
Ravikayr sits on rich volcanic soil in the interior of Beinland. Here, on the lower slopes of the dark Oskfjal mountain, much of the island's supply of grain is grown.

The legendary Queen Eshora, it is said, punished the jinn who were harassing her people by imprisoning them in one of the caves above Qasira, carving the mystical eight-pointed star into the rock to seal them in. She sentenced them to haul water from the depths of the earth, feeding the springs that gush forth from the rocks and which for centuries have irrigated the gardens of the Khisba, the small but rich coastal plain that adjoins the city.

The village of Agilting on the eastern shores of the Byalic Sea began as a gathering point for local fishers and herders to resolve their claims and feuds. Like many such sites in the north, it has evolved into a village as local populations grew.

Ortysia, named for the quails who inhabit the nearby coastal marshes, was the first Calradian colony on the shores of the Perassic Sea. In its early centuries, it fell under the authority of the Kannic city-state of Quyaz, but the Empire's expansion soon united the colony with its mother republic. For centuries, sailors coming from the pirate-infested islands of the Gulf of Charas gave thanks when they saw its towers looming through the haze of the western Perassic, signalling a return to safe imperial-patrolled waters.

Jalskveg, in the east of the Nordvyg north of Thronderlag, lies on one of the main routes from the coast to the more sparsely populated interior. The area is thick with ancient oak trees, which are harvested and dragged to the coast by oxen for use in shipbuilding.

Ortongard sits near the eastern edges of the Devseg plateau. The land is dry for most of the year but offers rich grazing in the spring. Founded by Darshi-speaking merchants, it made its wealth buying horses, sheep and cattle from the surrounding herding villages and sending them west to the markets of the Empire in huge drives, accompanied by guards to ward off raiders from the steppes. Neither its walls nor its mercenary armies could withstand the coming of Khan Urkhun, however, who granted it to the Khergit clan in recognition of their valor.

Sirindac lies beneath the high ridges of the Ebor peninsula, somewhat sheltered from the bitter winds blowing out of the northwest. It was settled by prospectors hunting for silver in the mountain streams, but that has mostly been exhausted and the region now mostly exports clay for local potters.

Razih is said to be the base from which Kannic explorers set forth to colonize the shores of the Perassic Sea in the centuries before the coming of the Empire, the prows of their ships decorated with the intertwined vine leaves of the Kannic goddess of wealth, wine, love and war. Today, the Kannic tongue has been replaced by Nahasawi dialects and their religion is all but forgotten, but the symbol lives on, said to protect those who risk all for the sake of gain or glory.

Drapand sits near the tip of Cape Fal, a promontory just south of the mouth of the Trand River. The foremost seafaring village on this coast, it gives its name to the bay to its north. The villagers venture out far into the seas to hunt right and blackfish whales, and sometimes range as far north as Beinland chasing bowheads and narwhals.

Zeonica sits by the seaside at the base of the Iltaric Hills, a land of wine, grain and horses. It was named for the Lady Zeona, one of the few women to rule the Empire - admittedly as regent for her son rather than Empress Regnant. It is known for the Zeonic Wind, a gale that blows northward across the Perassic Sea every summer carrying the burning heat of the Nahasa desert to the imperial south. In other seasons the weather here is mild, a weather pattern that has provided many a poet with a metaphor for the transience of passion.

Mjallagdal sits in a thickly wooded valley inland from Gretysfjord. Trees in these woods are often marked with the glyph of an horned archer carved into the bark, the work of a villager invoking the help of the god Ulthin in their hunt for marten, squirrel and other fur-bearing animals.

Thronderlag was the gathering place of the Throndar, the legendary progenitors of the Nordic realm. Here, overlooking the sea, the clans would assemble on the cold spring equinox to resolve their disputes, choose a target for summertime raiding, and elect a warleader. Today the Nord king takes counsel mainly with a select group of his jarls in his hall, and such great assemblies are no longer held, but Thonderlag remains the symbolic center of the Nordvyg.

Ruvenbrek sits in the far northeast of the lands settled by the Nords. Rich deposits of iron ore in the soil here, their wealth visible from rust-brown streaks on hillsides or in the waters of bogs, have drawn migrants to this otherwise remote and forbidding region.

Ykerslund is one of the northernmost districts of the Nordic kingdom. Its first inhabitants settled around a grove sacred to a wilderness goddess, and every year sacrifice in the hope of receiving her blessing to hunt in nearby woods.

Oristocorys lies on a peninsula west of the Bay of Ortysia. The village sits high on a slope to avoid both mosquitos from coastal marshes and raiding corsairs from the south, but the villagers make their way each morning to the sheltered covers where they keep their boats and set out to catch tuna, swordfish and other large species that migrate through the bay.

Ocs Hall is one of the few towns in the Vlandian kingdom that was founded after the seizure of the land from the Empire. This valley was once an isolated holdout of Battanians, centered on the Llyn Modris, a marshy pool said to be the court of a watery spirit-queen to whom the peoples of the region made offerings. It was conquered however by the Vlandian warlord Oca, who drained the pool for farmland and built his great hall on the heights above. The Battanian tribes were driven inland, over the Rhennod, and took their legends with them.

Paravenos was the second major colony founded by Calradios the Great, and it soon succeeded Charasea as the capital of the Calradians. Eventually, the Empire's center of gravity moved east, but Paravenos retained its primacy as the economic center of the West. When Osric Iron-Arm the Vlandian invaded, he recognized Paravenos would be far more valuable as a seat of power than as simply as a source of loot, and negotiated its surrender with local senators. It passed to a cadet branch of Osric's line, the dey Tihr clan, and is today known as Pravend.

Gretysfjord is perhaps the oldest walled town in the Nordvyg, yet there are greybeards here who claim their grandsires were among the first to settle here permanently. At first it was but a seasonal market by the shore, drawing in traders from across the seas, until a local chief built walls and a great hall and began calling himself jarl. It is still the most frequented port on the Nordvyg, a welcome refuge to sailors from the unpredictable and cold northern seas.

Mot lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills, known for the blaze of poppies that cover its slopes in the spring. The warm lands of the Vlandian south are well-suited to the growing of olives.

The village of Lagshofn was founded by the explorer and trade Lag, who cast his seat-pillars into the sea and followed them to this spot. His intrepid descendants sail from here into the straits between Hvalvik and Vlandia, where they hunt right whales, blackfish and other quarry on their migration routes between the Byalic Sea and the northern ocean.
Troverag is a mining colony in the bleak hills overlooking the Byalic Sea. The dour inhabitants are known for laboring long into the night, and the glow of their forges can be seen far from shore.

Omor sits on the eastern shores of Lake Laconis. Long before the Sturgians formed themselves into a principality it was a holy site for the forest tribes, who worshipped their gods and ancestors in the sacred oak trees of the nearby woods. Today, it is an emporium for fur trappers and woodsmen, and the primeval peace of the forests is drowned out by the sounds of bartering, saws, and the unloading of ships at the lake.

Khimli sits in a basin in the Devseg plateau. Though this land is dry most of the year, it experiences winter snowfalls and muddy springs. Fine clay can be collected from the pools left by the snowmelt and the rains.

Faergap lies on the passage through the bleak hills that divide the eastern coasts of the Byalic Sea from the Jumne valley. As the pass crests, and the rich lands of the Jumne come into view, a traveller can read runic inscriptions carved on boulders by Nordic migrants, giving thanks to the gods for their safe journey.

Sibir was founded on the seaward slopes of the Chertyg Mountains by Nordic traders, who wished a base to buy furs from the local Vakken-speaking foresters. As the Sturgian tribes became principalities, and elected chieftains evolved into boyars who demanded taxes and labor as their due, this region became a magnet for Sturgians who had little taste for deference. Today, the ambitious Isyaroving family governs this region, but they must always balance their hunger for wealth and men to fight their wars with their subjects' reluctance to provide it.

Arromanc lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills. The warm lands of the Vlandian south, where the air smells of sage, lavender and thyme, are well-suited to the growing of olives.

Vorfjall lies on the hills east of the Jumne, known for the bloom of purple lupin that fill the highland meadows in the late spring. The village sustains itself mining salt from deposits, some in vibrant streaks of color, that can be found in the nearby hills.
Elvania overlooks the estuary of the Aminys River. Hot southern afternoons and sea-cooled mornings make this good country for wine grapes.

Car Banseth sits on the bay that the Battanians used to call Muir Mon. The seafaring clans of this coast claim that the ancestors of the Battanians came across these waters to settle their lands. They say that those who keep faith will one day witness from this high point the ships of the vanished High King Mon, who shall return to deliver his people from their enemies. But today, they call it the Muir Gal, the foreigner's sea, as one is far more likely to see the sails of Nordic adventurers and mercenaries, coming to join Sturgians, Vlandians and others in their relentless push into Battanian land.

Midskag is named after the cape that lies roughly halfway from the western end of the Nordvyg to the capital of Thronderlag. The villagers of the region near Midskag make their living from the sea, harvesting cod and ice-char from nearby banks.

Phycaon sits at the head of the Sethys valley, one of the main grain-producing regions of the central Empire. Once the largest of the Palaic cities, its leaders led a league of the tribes against imperial encroachment into the region. But when the Empire's victory looked inevitable, they made their peace. The population, now thoroughly Calradicized, have a reputation for being serious, respectable and trade-minded, dependable if a bit humorless.

Kargrev was once Car Gryff, the ringfort of the Battanian chief Gryff, but was conquered by the Sturgians two generations ago. Recently, the most intrepid of the villagers have joined Nords and others who go every summer to the far north, to Beinland and beyond, in search of walrus ivory.
