Sahel sits on the edge of the Bay of Qasira, beneath the red sandstone Jabal Ashabi mountains. This ridge catches rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea and are brushed by monsoons from the southeast, allowing cistern-watered fields of flax.

Asmait lies in a nook of the red sandstone Jabal Ashabi mountains, bordered to the south by the deep desert. Villagers trap floods running down the hills during rare rainstorms, using the water to grow date palms and other crops.
Ain Baliq is clustered around a well between the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpmen. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.

Deir Hawa sits perched on the slopes of a mesa in the Jarjara Escarpment. This windswept bluff was once a refuge for religious ascetics, but their isolation came to an abrupt end when one of the curious pilgrims who came to visit them spotted the gleam of silver in the surrounding rocks. Prospectors have long exhausted the richest veins, but the villagers who live here today practice a number of close-guarded techniques to extract the precious metal from the ores that remain.

Qidnar sits on the landward side of the Jarjara Escarpment, looking down onto the deep desert of the central Nahasa. Here, the fierce rains that come once every few years fall onto rocky hills replete with clefts and crevaces, and can be diverted with channels into peaceful palm-gardens.
Jamayeh lies on the eastern end of the Jabal Minshar, a sharp sandstone ridge that runs parallel to the coast. Here the villagers grow olive trees overlooking the nearby Bay of Qasira.

Shibal Zumr lies where the Nahr al-Kals, the river of lime, comes down from the coastal hills to meet the Tiagys. Here the waters are pure and the soil is fertile, and grain is grown. But a short distance to the east, the land becomes barren and alkaline, and only the hardiest crops survive.
Uqba sits on the coastal plain of the Perassic Sea, which the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. Villagers trap rainwater and runoff from the hills to water their fields and their gardens of date-palms.

Bunqaz sits at the mouth of the wadi that divides the Jarjara Escarpment from the granite outcrop of the Jabal Tamar. Villagers sink wells here to tap the wadi's groundwater, using it to irrigate their olive groves.

Tamnuh lies near the southern end of the Jabal al-Kals, the bitter hills. The nearby castle guards the coastal land route between the Empire and the Aserai lands, a highway used by caravans and armies for thousands of years.

The oasis-village of Barihal sits in a wadi between the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment and the granite outcrop of the Jabal Tamar. The land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.

Ab Comer sits on the Etircomb, the steep valley which climbs from the Vlandian coastal plain to the Uchalion plateau, cut by the small creeks feeding the Trand River. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Llanoc Hen sits at the foot of the Cafalcombe that climbs from the western imperial lands to the Uchalion massif. Oak and other trees grow thick in the valley, providing nuts and thick roots to feed the local hogs.

Cantrec sits in the rocky Cafalcombe that climbs up from the imperial lands into the plateau of the Uchalion. The lands is not especially fertile here, but pigs thrive in the bush and shrubland of the heights.
Druimmor sits at one of the highest points on the Uchalion massif, the mountain fastness at the heart of the Battanian realm. Miners here have found silver in clefts in the hillsides.

Pendraic sits on a high outcrop beneath the lofty Ben Callach, said to have been a stone dropped by the divine crone Callach as she swept over the Uchalion bringing winter storms from the north. To the west it overlooks the Llyn Tywal lake, and to its south a steep pass that is traditionally one of the main routes between the Battanian heartland on the Uchalion massif and the Empire. The villagers raise hogs here on acorns which grow from oak trees on the heights.

Rhemtoil lies beneath a cleft in the eastern escarpment of the Uchalion plateau. A waterfall cascades down the cliffside here to form River Miron, which the Battanians call the Myr. This is among the most fertile of the Battanian lands, and produces a fine crop of wheat.
Claig Ban sits nestled in a small hollow amid the heights of the Uchalion massif. The clays of this region are much prized for their vivid red hues.

Flintolg sits on the so-called Stairs of Morac, a series of trails that run up the more accessible slopes of the Ailta Druin escarpment. The soil is poor but the woods grow thick here, making this the source of much of the timber used in the Battanian lands.

Glintor sits on a bluff towards the bottom of the Ailtra Druin cliffs, looking down upon the sea that the Battanians call the Muir Gal. Horses are raised on patches of rich pastureland in the glens between the crags, much prized by both raiders and traders from the Sturgian across the water.

Aster perches amid the crags of the Ailtra Druin, between the heights of the Uchalion and the sea. The people of this region have the reputation of being more focused on trade than warfare, and tribal elders have encouraged the planting of vineyards to produce a particularly strong vintage of wine.

Uthelaim sits on the eastern frontiers of the Battanian lands on a ridge overlooking a tributary of the Myr, just before it rushes down the slope towards Lake Laconis, and the Empire. The people of these parts are foresters, felling the oak, yew and pine of the woods for sale to builders and shipwrights.

Lochana is named for a castle that guards the Carcasos river. Along with Epinosa, its twin on the opposite bank, it forms the centuries-old border defense of this far-flung corner of empire against raiders from the north. The nearby sea tempers the cold of the northern winters here, allowing the cultivation of mulberry bushes for silk.
Rhesos sits amid the jumbled ridges of the Lesser Dryatic Mountains. Highland cattle thrive on the grasses of the heights.
Gaos sits in a broad valley in the Myzead, the rugged highlands in the east of the Empire. Nomadic herders once occupied this land, and the village's name is taken from their word for cattle.

Atrion lies by the delta of the Nevys, a cold, slow-moving river that drains into Lake Laconis. The land here was mostly marsh until a well-financed consortium of imperial gentry built dykes to reclaim it. Today they cultivate mulberry bushes, used to produce silk.

Epinosa sits on a tongue of land surrounded by rivers, the names of which reflect the long history of trade and conflict in this vital crossroads. The northern branch is known as the Caracasos, a name which derives from the Sturgian Karakaz, which itself derives from a Khuzait language. The Nords know it as the Jumne, a word derived from the Sturgian word for barrow. The southern branch is known to all the peoples of this region as the Davuna. The villagers here raise cattle on the thick grass of the riverside marches.

Pons was named for a bridge across the Caracasos River, though that was washed out generations ago in a flood and replaced by other crossings both upstream and downstream. The locals mine deposits of salt from nearby hills.
Syratos sits at the the base of Mount Tarnea, west of Lake Tanaesis. Flax grows well here, in the cold damp valley floor.

Tememos lies where the Plain of Ichala rises to meet the highlands of the Myzead. Horses graze on the mountain slopes in the summers and are taken to the valley floor when grasses sproud there after the winter rains.

Mecalovea sits on a rocky shelf of the Dryatic Mountains, surrounded on three sides by the Miron River and its tributary streams. This site affords it some protection from the raiders and brigands who plague this frontier region. The fast-flowing water has cut through the rock to expose rich seams of iron ore.

Agalmon sits in a valley in the Dryatic Mountains. The soil here is rich for a highland region, and the villagers have learned how to use terracing and other techniques to coax grain out of the mountain soil.

Odrysa lies near the Aserai frontier at the Calsean Gates, where the hills come down almost to the sea. The boulders here are covered with thousands of years of graffiti, in Calradic, in Nahasawi, Darshi, Kannic and a dozen other languages, from conquerors' triumphant declarations to their soldiers' homesick complaints. Though this area is dry, cedars and other trees grow in gorges in the hills, sustaining a small lumber industry.

Corenia is one of the farthest flung villages of the Empire to speak the Calradic tongue. It lies in the north of the Tanaetic Plain, on the shores of Lake Tanaesis. Villagers grow grain here, keeping watch for raiders from across the frontiers.

Metachia lies on the southern shores of Lake Tanaesis, where the coastal plain begins to climb towards the ridges of the Myzead. This imperial colony, established in more peaceful times, is a center for mulberry bushes used in silk production.

Melion sits in a narrow valley near the center of the Myzead, the rugged highlands in the east of the Empire. Villagers here cultivate mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested and fed to silkworks, producing thread much valued by both refined imperial nobles for their courtwear and hard-riding nomads and frontiersmen, who wear it beneath their armor as an extra layer of protection against arrows.
Sagolina sits at the foot of a narrow valley at the southern end of the Myzead, the rugged highlands of eastern Calradia. Villagers mine salt from deposits in the hills.

Lavenia sits on the northeastern shores of the Perassic. The people of this region sustain themselves by fishing, but also by serving on merchant vessels that haul cargos across the great inland sea, the imperial fleets that protect them, or the corsairs that prey on them.

Ethemisa lies in a low valley in the Thymian Hills. This region was once barren and mostly deserted, save for the hermits and visionaries who made their homes in its limestone caves. Ethemisa was home to some of the first permanent migrants, who tapped wells on the valley floor to irrigate their fields. According to legend, they demanded that one of the holy recluses here serve as their leader and guide them to virtue. At first he refused, but Heaven sent a flock of goats to follow him everywhere, disturbing his solitude, until he at least repented.
Morenia sits overlooking the Sethys River. Villagers collect clay from the riverbanks for the kilns of the imperial southlands.

Sestadaim sits on the western side of the great Ornian Rock, looking over the dry Plain of Ichala. Some say the vultures for which the rock is named once gathered here to feast on the bodies of those who died working the local salt mines.
Chanopsis sits near the headwaters of the Sethys River. Wheat grows well on the sun-baked slopes of the valley.

Garontor gives its name to the straits that join the Gulf of Charas and the inland Perassic Sea, the Gates of Garontor. Coastal meadows, where tall grasses tolerant of the ocean salt-spray thrive, support the rearing of fine horses.

Thorios sits in the Temea Valley in the heart of Calradia. Ample rainfall, rich soil and the relatively warm inland climate ensure that the grain fields of this district feed much of the central empire.
Bergum sits in the Temea Valley in the heart of Calradia. Rich soil, ample rainfall and the warm inland climate ensure that the grain fields of this district feed much of the central empire.
Onica lies in the Iltaric Hills, north of the Perassic Sea. The slopes of this district are terraced with vineyards, producing a dry wine popular throughout the Empire.
Thractorae sits on the hills above a small bay that feeds into the larger Gulf of Charas. Oaks grow thick around the streams running down to the sea, allowing hogs to forage acorns and roots.
Veron lies on the Gavys River, the westernmost tributary of the Aminys. The hills above the town are lined with vineyards which thrive in the well-drained, sandy soil.
Goleryn sits in the warm valley of the Gavys, where the river brushes by an outcrop of the Epiric Hills. Sheep-raising is a way of life in these parts, as is sheep-rustling.
Gersegos sits on a northern spur of the great basalt plutonic slab of Mount Erithrys. Villagers have sunk mines into the cliffs that overlook the village, extracting silver and other precious metals.

Usek sits atop an escarpment of the Akkan Hills on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.
Akiser sits in the southern reaches of the Akkan Hills. The land here is exceptionally broken and weathered, revealing seams of iron in the sides of the gullies and ravines.

The village of Hakkun sits beneath the escarpment of the Akkan Hills. The people of these parts have long mined silver from the mountains, a trade that the Khuzait khans were happy to encourage when they conquered this region.

Tepes sits in forested lowlands between the Devseg plateau and the lake that the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. This district specializes in the harvest of timber, which is dragged by oxen to the water and then floated to the lake towns.

Dinar lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, along the Karakaz River. Here, tribes recently arrived from the steppe have intermarried with refugees pushed south from the Jumne valley by recent Nord expansion. The villagers herd sheep out on the open grassland of the steppe.

The villagers of Simira raise cattle by the grassy shores of the Tiagys River, known to the Khuzaits as the Teyagh. The river here still runs fast after its descent from the hills, and in springtime the villagers have learned to watch closely for signs of a flood that will force them to get their herds to higher ground.

Kaysar sits in the north and east of the lands ruled by the Khuzaits, in the valley of the Karakaz River. This district is snowbound for much of the year, but villagers still raise herds of cattle bred to withstand the icy winds coming downriver from the north.

Payam lies alongside the Davana River in the cold north of the Khuzait lands, not far from where it joins with the Karakaz and runs down to the sea. Though the land is snowbound much of the year, the villagers sow wheat and barley as soon as the melt starts, taking in a good crop before the autumn.

Ustokol sits on the windswept Kachyar Peninsula, between the Battanian and Byalic seas. Hardy northern cattle have been bred to eat the short grasses that grow among the rocks, supplemented by sea-kelp in hard times.
Mazhadan sits on the forested western shores of Lake Laconis. Villagers grow flax in the muddy valleys between the hills.

Nevyansk sits at the foot of a fortified outcrop that the Sturgians call Minador. The towers that stand today are used by the Sturgians to keep watch over the rich but vulnerable wheatfields in these borderlands. Beneath the Sturgian walls however are foundations laid when the fortress was known by its Battanian name, Mynad Rhyfel, the hill of war, and the Sturgians have no doubt that their neighbors to the west would very much like to take it back.

Dnin sits on pastures overlooking the great bay that the Sturgians call the Battanian Sea. Horses graze on the heights, glancing down occasionally at the trading longships and fishing boats passing beneath them.
Kranirog sits near a ridge at the beginning of the Kachyar Peninsula. The villagers in these parts are expert trappers, hunting marten, fox and rabbit for the rich pelts much in demand in the south.

Ismilkorg sits in the Irkaria hill country between Lake Laconis and the gulf that the Sturgians call the Battanian Sea. The people here are mostly cattle-herders as well as cattle-rustlers, and have long traded raids with the imperial frontier villages to the south and Battanians to the west.

Ov is a recently settled Sturgian colony on the high wooded slopes over the Mazapor estuary. Sturgians came to this region in search of furs, but game has been driven further west into yet-unsettled lands and these days the residents raise flax in meadows amids the woods.

Ferkh lies in a valley at the western edge of the Chertyg Mountains. It serves as a base for traders venturing further into the highlands, braving cold, wolves and the sometimes-hostile, sometimes-friendly peoples of the woods in pursuit of fur, the bounty of the northlands.

Takor is a cattle-raising village in the heart of the Chertyg Mountains. The term 'Takorski' is used by other Sturgians to refer to someone whose speech is unintelligible. Above the village, small wisps of smoke show where wandering Vakken forest dwellers make their temporary fields, sowing them for one or two seasons before moving elsewhere.
Urikskala sits on a bluff overlooking the eastern shores of Lake Laconis. The eastern edge of the lake is rich with fish, including massive pike and sturgeon that breed in the nearby Karakaz estuary.
Vladiv lies on a plain to the northeast of Mount Iltan. The hardy cattle of this region have learned to dig through thick winter snows in search of grass to sustain them until the spring.
Usanc sits on the slopes of the Epiric Hills, overlooking the Gulf of Charas. This warm southern land supports the growing of olive trees.
Ferton sits at the base of the Biscan Hills. This warm coast, fragrant with lavender and thyme, is well-suited to the growing of olives..
Tirby looks out onto the cold misty waters that lie off of the Ebor peninsula. The low-lying lands on the northern side of the Ebor are suited to the growing of flax.
Deriat sits just inland of the Bay of Drapand. Villagers here raise hogs, herding them to the nearby highlands to forage for nuts and roots.
Verecsand sits in the lowlands of the Trand valley. Villagers here grow wheat in the gentle downs by the meandering river.

Baq lies slightly inland from the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, beneath the great granite outcrop of the Jabal Tamar. The seawinds bring the uplands here just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.

Fanab lies at the feet of the granite outcrop known as the Jabal Tamar, on the peninsula between the bay that the Aserai call the Bay of Shariz and the inner sea of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The seawinds bring just enough rain to support the cultivation of olive trees.

Hiblet sits on the peninsula between the gulf that the Aserai call the Bay of Shariz, and the sea they call the Bahr al-Yeshm. The rainclouds that sweep across this land drop sufficient water to fill the village's cisterns and irrigate its date-palm gardens.

Abu Khih is the southernmost village of the Aserai sultanate in the valley of the Tiagys. The lands here are dotted with crumbling brick towers, the ruins of cities that once thrived here under the Darshi shahs, before steppe nomads came and broke the levees that tamed the river. Years of devastating floods, followed by famines, reduced the population of this land to a fraction of what it once was.

Hoqqa sits besides the meandering waters of the Tiyagis plain. Villagers grow crops close to the river, but the land quickly gives way to desert-steppe. Barren most of the year except for scrub, it is covered in grass and flowers in the spring and is fine grazing for horses.

Abba sits in a broad wadi of the Jarjara Escarpment, close to the outlet where the rains that fall once every few years rush down to the sea. Runoff from the hills is trapped underground here, sustaining an oasis. Wheat thrives in the fields and gardens.

Hunab lies in the Sahel al-Wuhush, the Plain of Beasts, weathered mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Although the name comes from the mysterious petroglyphs of animals found caved throughout the valley, it could just as well refer to the fine steeds reared today, fed on the lush if short-lasting crop of grass that covers the slopes in the spring.

Qablab sits on a bluff of the rust-red Jabal Ashabi hills, overlooking the towers and harbor of Razih. Every morning, villagers leave the jasmine- and thyme-scented hills to descend to the thick air of the coast, where they harvest salt from artificial lagoons.

Mussum sits near the eastern coast of the Perassic Sea, which the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. Here, the deserts of the far south give way to desert-steppe with scattered acacia and scrub. The villagers here sink wells to water their groves of date palms.

Mahloul in the Sahal al-Wuhush, the Plain of Beasts, that cuts through the Jarjara Escarpment south of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The valley takes its name from the mysterious petroglyphys of hoofed and horned animals carved on boulders scattered about. Groundwater provides just enough water to grow crops for subsistence, while the village makes its money from rearing horses on the rich grass that grows in clefts in the escarpment after the spring rains.

Liwas sits in the seaward end of the Sahal al-Wuhush, the Plain of Beasts. This broad valley runs between the Jabal Minshar, a sharp sandstone ridge near the coast, and the inland mesas of the Jarjara escarpment. Although the valleys name comes from the mysterious petroglyphs found here of horned and hoofed animals, it could just as well refer to the splendid horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.

Waltas sits by the Bay of Qasira, an inlet of the sea that the Aserai call the Bahr al-Yeshm. The ridges of the nearby Jabal Ashabi mountains catch rainclouds coming off the Bahr al-Yeshm sea, allowing for the growing of wheat.

Mijayit lies off of the estuary of the Damar river as it reaches the Bahr al-Yeshm sea. The rich silt deposits left by the river make this one of the most fertile regions and densely populated regions of the Aserai lands.
Nahlan sits on the floodplain of the Damar River as it cuts through the Jarjara Escarpment. This soil, refreshed yearly by the silt of the flooding river, produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Bait Hatif lies in one of the wadis that are cut through the Jarjara Escarpment by the rare but fierce desert rains. Wells tap the groundwater here and allow subsistence farming, but the wealth of the land comes from the fine horses raised on the grasses that grow on the heights in the spring.

Zalm sits at the Scorched Gates, where the Damar River descends from the Nahasa Desert and starts its journey through the Jarjara Escarpment. The silt brought by the river produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Ezbet Nahul lies in the middle of the Khisba, a small but rich coastal plain protected from the deserts by the Jabal Minshar. Villagers tap every source of available freshwater, from cisterns, wells in the ground, or rain-traps in the hills, to devote to the growing of wheat to feed nearby Qasira.
Dalmengus sits by the side of the Llyn Tywal, the dark lake at the center of the Uchalion massif. The flat, well-watered lands here are fertile and well-suited to wheat and barley.

Ebereth is one of several villages on the densely populated southern shores of the Llyn Tywal, the dark lake at the heart of the Battanian lands. The people here here grow grapes to make the sweet white wine of the Battanian lands.

Beglomuar sits at the crest of the Cafalcombe. The soil is thin and rocky, and there is little to recommend these lands other than the ore deposits in the hills and the bog-iron of the mountain marshes.
Ath Cafal sits near the head of the Cafalcombe, a steep valley that descends to the imperial lands. The villagers gather fine clay from local streambeds to trade to the potters of nearby towns.

Diantogmail lies in winding valleys in hill country to the east of Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. There are a half-dozen local legends explaining how the region got its name, which means the 'Flight of the Stoat,' but no two of them match in any particulars. Villagers here gather clay from the lakeside for use by nearby artisans.
Morihig lies in the Morcomb, a valley on the western side of the Uchalion massif. The region is known for its production of wheat and barley.
Imlagh lies below the heights of the Ailta Druin, overlooking the Muir Gal sea. The village specializes in white grapes for the making of the sweet Battanian wines.
Bog Beth sits in a forested glen at the seaward side of Ben Callach mountain. Villagers trap beavers, foxes and other fur-bearing animals in the dark, marshy woods.

Geunat Nal, the village where Nal left his head, is a fur-trapping village near the site of a duel famous in Battanian legend. The villagers are known for their skill as foresters, helping the nearby sea-fort of Car Banseth to guard the northern approaches to the Battanian heartland from Sturgian and other raiders.

Tor Leiad, the hill of the full moon, lies beneath a wooded knoll in a small patch of Battanian lowland near Car Banseth. Villagers harvest the thick-growing forests of oak, yew and beech that grow on the heights above their homes. The woods here have been tended carefully by the Battanians for centuries, ensuring that there are always enough trees to harvest and sell for timber.
Bryn Glas sits on the eastern shores of the Llyn Tywal. Villagers raise grapes on the slopes, making a strong, dark red wine highly valued by the Vlandians and the Empire.
Andurn sits on a grassy down overlooking Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. The villagers of these parts tend the forests, harvesting beech, oak and yew for sale to the towns.
Swenryn gives its name to the waterfall that cascades down the cliffs at the eastern edge of the Uchalion. Horses graze in lush pastures fed by the mists.

Seordas sits in the lowlands at the eastern edge of the Battanian lands, at the foot of the Uchalion's cliffs. The land is watered by the tributaries of the Myr River and the soil is rich, but in wartime there are few natural protections against the maraudings of Sturgian and imperial raiders.

Durn sits just below the crags that form the crest of the Etircomb, the steep valley that climbs from the Vlandian coastal lowlands to the Uchalion massif. Villagers scrape mud from mountain creekbeds, carting it up the winding paths to the town of Pen Cannoc perched on the cliff above them.
Gainseth sits in dense woods that grow near the stronghold of Pen Cannoc. Villagers collect mud from the marshy ground for sale to the potters of Pen Cannoc.

Fenon Etir lies in the Etircomb, the steep valley that leads from the Vlandian coastal lowlands to the Uchalion massif. The trails to the village pass by mounds of slag, the detritus from centuries of mining the iron-rich ores of the nearby hills, exposed by the creeks that run down from the heights.

Inveth sits where the River Etir forms from streams that tumble down the Uchalion massif before reaching the coastal lowlands, where they feed into the Trand. The surrounding hillsides support the growing of wheat.

Stathymos lies by a tributary of the Miron River, north of the Dryatic Mountains. The nearby hills have several hot springs, whose faint whiff of sulfur has made Stathymos one of several villages in the Empire who claim to have once been plagued by dragons who were eventually slain by bold cataphracts.
Dyopalis lies in a valley in the Lesser Dryatic Mountains. Despite the cold winters, the region's fertile soils make this district one of the breadbaskets of the northern Empire.
Alosea lies on the southern shores of Lake Laconis. The folk of this region live well off the pike and sturgeon of the lake.

Jeracos sits in meadowland in the northern piedmont of the Dryatic Mountains. The slopes of the nearby hills are pierced with mineshafts. Despite centuries of use, they still yield ores from which silver can be extracted through various cunning techniques.
Enoisa sits by the cold, slow-moving River Nevys as it makes its way towards Lake Laconis. Wheat grows here, fed by the ample rains of the north.

Aeoria sits in the fertile Vale of the Aris, where the river winds between parallel granite ridges. The dialect here is laced with words from Palaic, the language spoken in the center of the continent before the Empire came.

Crios sits besides the River Aris as it descends into the Ophthys, the dark pool that lies at the foot of Mount Tarnea. Shrines built by the ancient Palaic people, who believed the lake was a gateway to another worgendsd, can be found along its shores.

Potamis sits at the edge of the Temea Valley, near the foothills of the Dryatic Mountains. The people of these parts have raised cattle since pre-Calradic times, and its milk and butter are sought out by traders and travellers passing through the region.

Nortanisa is a fishing village on the western shores of Lake Laconis. Villagers place nets and cages in the shallow edges of the lake and the nearby estuary of the Caracasos to catch roach, bream, perch, and crayfish.

Hetania sits beneath a low ridge in the Lesser Dryatic Mountains. As in many villages around here, the foresters of this region still speak the Dryatic languages of the tribes who lived here before the Empire came.

Vealos sits in a thickly wooded valley in the eastern end of the Myzead, the rugged highlands of the eastern Empire. Retired imperial officers have founded stud farms here, grazing their horses on the rich pasture on the slopes of the heights.

Orthra, a relatively recent settlement, was named by an imperial captain for its fine southward views over the Myzead, the mountainous highlands of the eastern empire. It was founded as a stud farm to breed imperial horses with steppe stock from the east, and continues to provide horses for the imperial cavalry.
Themys lies under a ridge of limestone crags in the Myzead, the mountainous highlands of the eastern Empire. The grasses on the rolling downs are well-suited to the raising of sheep.

Samatha sits upon a sloping ridge in the highlands of the Myzead. The hillsides have been terraced to allow the growing of mulberry bushes. The leaves are harvested, placed in vats and fed to silkworms.

Avasinton sits in a valley of the Myzead, the mountainous highlands of the eastern Empire. Villagers have cleared away the thickets and thornbrush of this region, including the pungent wormwood after which the village is named, to allow the growing of mulberry bushes, the leaves of which are harvested and fed to silkworms.
Boreagora lies where the estuary of the Caracasos River reaches Lake Laconis. The lowlands here are suited to the growing of flax.

Caira sits in the humid plains east of Danustica. Here, the sea air of the Perassic is trapped by the Calsean Hills, creating a climate shunned by many other Calradians. For those used to the heat, however, the rich soils provide a good living, and the villagers are proud of their role guarding the frontier with the Aserai.

Polisia sits on the eastern end of the Thymian Hills. Villagers harvest salt from pans in a shallow inlet to their south, near the town of Danustica. They prefer to live up in the hills, however, away from the thick and fetid air and the mosquitos of the coast.

Tegresos sits amid woodland on the eastern end of the Thymian Hills, close to the Aserai and Khuzait domains. Originally it was settled in defiance of imperial authority by the bands of fugitives and adventurers known as the Eleftheroi, but the archons of Danustica eventually awarded this settlement a proper charter in exchange for helping to guard the frontiers.

The frontier village of Erebulos sits in woodland beneath the Calsean Hills. This village was settled by Eleftheroi, though it has since been integrated into the archonate of Danustica. Villagers scoop clay from creek-bottoms here, and keep watch for Aserai and Khuzait raiders trying to infliltrate the imperial frontiers through the woods.

The village of Atphynia lies in a valley in the Thymian Hills. The rocks here are speckled with sea-shells, while salt deposits lie in the valley, and villagers claim that this was once a bay of the sea uplifted by some great subterranean force.
Gorcorys sits on the Gorea, the southernmost tributary of the Sethys River. The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.
Avalyps sits on the narrow but fertile shelf of land between the Perassic Sea and the Thymian Hills. The dark, well-watered soil here makes this region an imperial breadbasket.

Alision lies in a nook of the Thymian Hills, north of the Perassic Sea. The rocks of this basin are lined with seashells, a long source of fascination to imperial philosophers who debate whether the earth experienced periodic inundations or if different portions are raised and lowered over time.

Canoros sits in the plains north of the Perassic Sea. This land has been good horse country since even before the Empire came, furnishing the steeds of the Lycarean riders who routed several Calradian armies before their final defeat and absorption into the imperial cavalry.

Tevea sits by the banks of the River Sethys, south of the Ornian Rock. This great outcrop is named for the vultures who perch on its crags to keep watch on the hazy plains below. The low-lying riverlands are used by the villagers to grow flax.
Sagora sits on a low ridge overlooking the River Sethys. This district is one of the rockier and less fertile parts of the river valley, but the valley scrub still supports the grazing of sheep.

Popsia lies on the eastern side of Mount Tarnea. Pelaic myth says that two gigantic brothers fought here and killed each other. Their sister Tarnea buried one in the depths of the Ophthys, the other in Lake Laconis, then transformed herself into the mountain to weep over their graves. Trees grow tall here in the cool shadows of the heights, and villagers harvest pines for sale as lumber.

Canterion lies by the Sethys River, between the Ornian Rock and the Thymian Hills. The rich grasses have made this land good horse country since even before the coming of the Empire, and today the village gives its name to the chargers prized by the imperial nobility.

Lanthas is one of the few settlements on the wide but barren Tanaetic Plain. This scrubland is good sheep country, but in a frontier district scoured by imperial fugitives, wild Eleftheroi riders and steppe nomads, the villagers here have learned to watch their flocks closely.

Lartusys lies on the eastern edge of the Tanaetic plain. The village sits near a deposit of salt, and salt springs occasionally bubble to the surface, feeding the legend that this was once a gateway to a haunted underground sea.

Parasemnos sits in a low pass linking the Tanaeitic plain with coastal lowlands near Danustica. Silver mines have long existed in the hills, although the deposits are no longer as rich as they once were, and the villagers must use closely-guarded secret methods to extract the precious metal.
Saldannis lies beneath bluffs overlooking the River Sethys. The fine soil of the hills makes for a sticky clay when it washes down to the river, much prized by the potters of the imperial south.
Spotia lies east of the gently flowing Sethys River. The low rolling hills of this district comprise one of the breadbaskets of the Empire.
Amycon lies on a ridge between the dry Plain of Ichala and the Sethys valley. The people of this land are sheep herders, known for their dry, salty cheese flavored with cumin.
Psotai sits on the western shores of Lake Tanaesis. The low-lying fields here are one of the major grain producing centers of the eastern frontier regions.
Primessos lies in the wooded upper reaches of the Aminys valley. Pigs, fed on the acorns of the southern oak trees, thrive in this climate.
Nideon sits on a low-lying spit of land where the Gavys, Aminys and Zeos rivers come together. Wine grapes grow on the gentle slopes rising up from the river valley.
Tarcutis sits on the shores of the Perassic Sea. The sandy soil and morning mists, channeled by offshore islands, allows the growing of grapes overlooking the beaches.
Neocorys, the new village, sits in gently sloping land in the Temea Valley cleared only recently of forest. The local landowners have established stud farms, supplying horses to the imperial cavalry.

Alsasos sits on a shelf of land at the west end of the Temea, a broad valley north of the Perassic sea. Though the climate is relatively dry here, artesian wells allow farmers to grow bountiful crops of wheat.
Zeocorys lies at the foot of a low escarpment that bisects the Temea Valley. Though the climate is relatively dry here, artesian wells allow farmers to grow bountiful crops of wheat.

Aegosca sits at the head of the Temea, a broad valley in southern Calradia. Though originally named for the goats that used to roam this region, the landowners have turned over the pastures to the raising of far more profitable horses.
Dradios sits near a bend in the Zeos River. Here the meandering waters have left a rich deposit of silt that sustains one of the breadbaskets of the Empire.
Arpotis lies close to where the Zeos and Gavys rivers join the Aminys and together reach the sea. This well-watered plain is one of the breadbaskets of the Empire.

Lysia sits on the promontory above the Gates of Garontor, the straits that link the Gulf of Charas with the Perassic. Salt is farmed from evaporation pans on the broad beaches that look out onto the gulf.
Garengolia lies near a rich vein of silver in the eastern end of the Epiric Hills. The Empire have minted its denars from these mines for centuries.

Elipa sits on the heights overlooking the Plain of Ichala, a sparsely populated ancient lake bed. The plain itself is dry and the soil saline, and is mostly empty grass and scrubland, but the heights above are fertile and receives ample rains.
Phasos sits amid rolling chalk uplands on the edge of the Temea Valley. The rich grass of the down is some of the best horse-breeding land in the Empire.

Vathea sits high on the slopes of the Dryatic Mountains, facing across the valley to the great basalt slab of Mount Erithrys. The villagers mine iron from shafts sunk deep into the cliffs of the mountains.

Thersenion lies in the shadow of Mount Erithrys, a great basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. The Gavys, Aminys amd Zeos rivers all come together in the plains beneath the mountain, making these lands one of the grain breadbaskets of the Empire.

Leblenion sits in the rolling hills of the Temea Valley east of Mount Erithrys, a great basalt slab thrust up from the depths of the earth. This warm land is one of the grain breadbaskets of the Empire.

Fisnar sits in the grasslands east of the Karakaz River. Snow-bound for much of the year, the spring grasses nonetheless sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from the bitter winter cold.

Ulaan sits where the land gently rises from the valley of the Karakaz River to the slopes of the Sulan Dag. The villagers, nomads who have recently been forced by the khans to settle, have learned to grow flax for their livelihoods.

Kuruluk sits in the shadow of the peak known as Bars Dag. Though this valley is snowbound for much of the year, steppe ponies thrive on the spring grasses and in the winter dig through the snow for food, their thick coats protecting them from the icy blasts of wind. Villagers keep watch to protect them from the leopards for which the mountain is named.

Asalig sits at the foot of the Sulan Dag mountains, dividing the northern Khuzait lands from the sparsely populated steppe to the east. Villagers raise horses in the lower slopes, keeping watch for the leopards that descend from the high peaks in the winter, when the game is scarce.
Karakalat lies at the southern end of the Akkan Hills. Until recently, this land was dominated by nomads, and it is still famous as a breeding ground for horses.

Tismil sits on the Ozu River, which drains the southern end of the Devseg plateau. The region is a center of horse-raising, as noyans seek to breed new larger warhorses that still retain the hardiness and adaptability of their ancestors' steppe ponies.

Gereden lies amid the foothills of the Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn, near the headwaters of the Kizil Tayegh River. The clay from this region, known for its reddish tint, is highly valued by the artisans of Odokh and other nearby towns.

The fishing village of Shapeshte sits on a bay in Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. Carp and catfish were introduced to the gentle murky waters of the lakeshore back when these lands were controlled by the Empire, and today make up the majority of the fishermen's catch.

The village of Mazen sits on the northern end of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The northern winters here are tempered by the lake, and the villagers raise mulberry trees here to feed silkworms.
Mivanjan sits near an escarpment of the Akkan Hills, which marks the western border of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, raise sheep in the foothills.

Kamshar sits beneath a low range of hills separating Lake Tanaesis from the western tributaries of the Tayegh River. by Villagers collect clay from the riverbed for sale to the potters of Chaikand and other towns.
Okhutan is a village at the center of a wheat-growing district on a narrow stretch of plain between the Akkan Hills and Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea.
Ispantar is a village on a rocky spur of the Akkan Hills overlooking Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers here make most of their income from the raising of sheep.
Pabastan sits in the narrow plain between the Akkan Hills and Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. This land is fine country for wheat.
Nutyuk sits in the plains of the upper Tiagys River, known by the Khuzaits as the Tayegh. The villagers here, mostly recently settled nomads, raise sheep like their ancestors.

Danara sits near the source of the headwaters of the Tiagys River in the foothills of the Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. Salt and sulfur springs flow out of fissures in the rock here, giving the waters of the river an acrid taste until, further down, they are diluted by other creeks and streams.
Kohi Ajik lies in a valley at the foot of the so-called Lover's Mountain, from which its name derives. To its east spring the headwaters of the Ozu River, one of the sources of the mighty Tiagys.

Rodobas, the house of Obas, is named for a long-dead Sturgian hill chieftain. Perched high on a ridge overlooking the rolling hills of Irkaria, it adjoins one of the few remaining virgin forests of this once-wild land. The village serves as a base for trappers looking for furs in the primeval gloom of the great trees.
Forin sits on grassy downs overlooking a tributary of the Miron River, on the edge of the wild forests of eastern Irkaria. Landowners here have turned forest-land into pasture for horses.
Safna in a valley in the rugged Chertyg Mountains. Villagers grow barley here, using it to make dumplings from the meat of mountain cattle that is sold in the markets of nearby towns.
Marabrot sits on a high rocky ridge between the Mazapor Estuary and the Byalic Sea. This harsh land would probably not be settled where it not for the rich iron deposits in the hills.

Dvorusta is a fishing village on the northern shores of Lake Laconis. The water is cold and pure here, thanks to the streams running down from the Chernyg mountains, and the village fishermen take in a rich catch of freshwater lake fish.

Chornobas, or Blackwood, sits in lands recently cleared from the forests in the hills of Irkaria. The villagers grow rye and barley to feed the booming port city of Omor. To the northeast, the lands for the most part remain wooded, although small wisps of smoke show where Sturgian settlers are beginning to cut down trees and sow fields.

Skorin lies in the heart of Irkaria, a patchwork of grassy downs and forests between the Battanian Sea and Lake Laconis. Villagers comb the remaining woods of these once-wild lands for signs of marten, mink, rabbit and other game, the fur of which is much valued by the merchants and magnates of northern Calradia.
Glavstrom sits on the eastern shores of the Byalic Sea. The craggy shores here are thick with rockfish, which the villagers catch with nets despite the turbulence of the waters.
Omkany in the heart of the icy Chertyg Mountains. Villagers in this district raise hogs, curing their fat with salt and in garlic and selling it throughout the northlands.
Yangutum sits in a nook of the Chertyg Mountains near the north shores of Lake Laconis. The foresters harvest oak, elm and other hardwoods from the mountainsides.

Visibrot is a sheep-rearing village on the lower slopes of Mount Iltan. Though this region is cold and remote, its importance as a trade juncture between Lakes Laconis and Tanaesis, between the Empire and the steppe, mean that it is relatively densely populated.
Bukits sits on the eastern slopes of Mount Iltan. Villagers raise highland cattle here, bred to withstand the icy gusts that tear down the mountain.

Alov overlooks the Iltan portages, a series of crossings over the Karakaz and Davana rivers. Villagers cultivate rye and barley on slopes leading down to the river, and the rich black soil of the region compensates for the long winters and short growing season.

Radakmed sits on the coasts of the Byalic Sea. Many of the families in the region trace their roots to Nords who migrated south, or Vakken who gave up their nomadic lives in the woods. Whatever lands they may have come from, the people of Radakmed have now taken to the sea. Their wanderlust not yet slacked, they sail far to the north each summer to hunt walrus, for flesh to eat, ivory to trade, and blubber to light lamps on long winter nights.

Alebat sits deep in the forests of northeastern Sturgia. This isolated region has long been a refuge for those fleeing oppression or debt or bloodfeud across the northlands, and the dialect is strongly influenced by the tongue of the Vakken woodspeople.
Karbur sits at a plateau on the Kachyar Peninsula. Sheltered somewhat by a high ridge to their north, the villagers here raise barley and grain.
Zhemyan lies on the ridge that forms the spine of the Kachyar Peninsula. The rich grassy fields of this region make it a prime spot for local landowners to raise horses.

Echarfurd sits on the northern slopes of the Epiric Hills. Unlike most settlements in the kingdom, it was founded by Vlandian migrants, who named it after a settlement in their old homeland. The villagers here grow wheat, finding a ready market in the garrisons stationed nearby.
Rodetan takes its name from the ruddy, iron-rich soil of this part of the the Biscan Hills. The mines of this district supply the iron ore for many of the forges of the Vlandian kingdom.
Mareiven sits in the Vlandian coastal lowlands, beneath the hills of the Rhennod. Villagers harvest the tall trees of the heights, selling the logs to cities on the coast.

Oritan sits high in the Rhennod, the western escarpment of the Uchalion massif. The families of this region trace their descent to Vlandian mercenaries who intermarried with local hill peoples related to the Battanians.
Fregian sits in a shallow valley near Ocs Hall. Villagers plant flax on boggy land that was once a marshy lake before it was drained by the Vlandian barons.
Marin lies on the edges of the broad valley of the meandering Trand. Misty mornings cooled by sea drifting south and warm afternoons make this land well-suited to the growing of grapes.
Rulund sits in the windswept coasts north of the Trand River. Although there are few forests in these parts for the pigs to root, they thrive on the rye and wheat grown on the downs by the sea.
Palisont sits close to where the Trand River meets the sea. The cool sea air that flows upriver and the warm afternoons allow the growing of wine grapes.
Furbec sits on a shelf overlooking the rocky Biscan coast of central Vlandia. The climate is warm most of the year, and grapes do well on the slopes of the Biscan Hills.
Savinth sits on a wooded hillside north of the Gulf of Charas. Just down the slope lies fine pasture for the renowned horses of the Vlandians.
The village of Vesin lies by a creek running down from the Epiric Hills to the Gulf of Charas. This warm land is well-suited to the growing of olive trees.

Cananc lies in the wet wooded hills of the Ebor Peninsula, where yew trees grow tall in the sea-mists. The village is known for producing fine pigs, who are allowed to range through the thick woods rooting for acorns, chestnuts and grubs. Towering fir and spruce grow on the slopes. This rule of of the Vlandian barons in this rugged land is much lighter than in the south, attracting many migrants who value the relative freedom.

Remental sits on a ledge of the Ebor Peninsula, overlooking the sea. Vlandian settlers originally here came to mine silver, but those ores were quickly exhausted. Desperate prospectors were able to locate some deposits of salt, which was much in demand as the coasts here are generally too steep for the creation of salt pans.
Alantas sits in the center of the mountainous Ebor Peninsula. The soil here is thin and the weather here is cold, but rich iron deposits sustain the local economy.
Halisvust was once a bog amid the scrubby coastal woods at the base of the Ebor Peninsula, but Vlandian settlers drained the waters and sowed wheat and rye.
Talivel lies in the middle of the Trand valley in the Vlandian heartland. Villagers plant olives here on the hillsides.

Revyl, chief town of the rocky Kachyar Peninsula, was a traditional rival of Balgard. According to legend the Balgardian princess Arkina, whose husband had been slain by the Revylians, accepted a proposal from her enemy's king to marry and settle the feud. On her wedding night, however, she barred the door of his hall and burned him and a hundred of his kinsmen and warriors alive inside. The feud has long since been settled by pacts and marriages with happier outcomes, although Revylians still resent the ascent of the Balgardian Gundaroving dynasty.

Haugr sits on the eastern branch of the Jumne River, where it meanders over its floodplain. It was named after a stone cairn on a riverside bluff, said by locals to have been built by trolls from the nearby tundra. The region produces fine, dark clays, much prized by local potters.
Calioc sits in the Neurval, the valley between the Epiric and Biscan Hills. The people of this district grow flax on the wet valley floor.

Galend overlooks the wave-beaten Biscan coast. It takes in the catch from the Biscan's intrepid fishermen and whalers who venture out far into the western ocean, as well as the wool of sheep from the green fog-covered hills. The current line of Vlandian kings comes from the clans who settled in this region during Osric Iron-Arm's invasion.
Omrotok sits at the foot of the Sulun Dag mountains, which mark the eastern border of the Devseg plateau. Villagers go to the nearby woods to harvest one of the Devseg's few sources of timber.

Gripsby, on the east coast of Beinland, was founded early in the island's settlement by mainlanders who hunted walrus on nearby beaches. These days they must venture farther afield, to the north of Beinland and the frozen seas beyond, but they still take a rich haul of valuable ivory.

The village of Nogrent sits high on a ridge overlooking the Biscan coast. Grapes grown here are pressed to make a sturdy wine, a key ingredient in the hearty fishermen's soups for which the Biscan region is famous.

Karahalli lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, in borderlands contested by Sturgians and Nords. Though the winters are cold, the spring grasses are fine grazing for the local sheep, whose thick wool protects them from the region's piercing winds.

The fishing village of Aalgrun is known for the eels that thrive in the offshore shallows. Slightly further out to sea fishermen also find herring, as well as char that migrates to the sea from nearby streams to spawn.

Ormanfard sits at the foot of the Ormanthal, a pass that leads to the Battanian lands. Rains are plentiful and wheat and barley grow well on the hillsides, but villagers are always alert for the sounds of horns from the castle guarding the pass, warning of Battanian raiders.

The natural fortress of Lycaron sits on a spur jutting out of the great Ornian rock. In the final years of the imperial conquest, the Palaic tribe here negotiated a peaceful federation with the Empire, only to see their home seized by the rebel leader Gethuz. The ensuing siege was only the first of many that Lycaron would undergo in the ensuing centuries, as its nearby silver mines made it a prize for every imperial pretender who ever tried to seize power in a civil war. It is said that the colony of vultures who inhabit the upper reaches of the Rock have dined on the flesh of every people of Calradia.

The frontier city of Danustica has long defended the eastern reaches of the Empire, holding the line against incursions by the Aserai and various Darshi shahs and padishahs further to the east. Many an imperial legionary stationed here has scribbled graffiti on its walls cursing the city's sweltering summers, brackish water and mosquitos, but the inhabitants are proud of their role as border defenders and mock the soldiers wilting in the heat around them.

Balgard, which sits on the icy waters of the Byalic Sea, was founded by migrants from the Nordvyg. Legend holds that the initial wave of Nords arrogantly demanded tribute from the nearby Vakken and Sturgian tribes, who formed an alliance and drove the newcomers back to their ships. But the victors fell out over the spoils, until a canny Nord, Gundar, landed and volunteered to help them fairly divvy up the weapons and armor of his dead kinsmen. The residents recognized Gundar's lordship over the region and his descendants, intermarried with the Sturgians, are today the grand princes of Sturgia.

The village of Draugmyr takes its name from a nearby bog that was once a place of sacrifice. Though long since drained to create farmland, its rich wheatfields still turn up the odd bone or golden grave-offering.
Marathea lies in a valley in the Dryatic Mountains, overlooking Lake Laconis. The villagers are skilled miners, and the red streaks running down the nearby cliffsides are evidence of rich iron ores.

Laxahof sits on a low promontory that juts into the Byalic Sea, on the war-torn marches that divide the Sturgian and Nordic lands. In past generations its inhabitants made their living by signing on to dangerous, freezing whaling ventures organized by Byalic Sea merchants. Rrecently they have begun to organize their own voyages, bringing home wealth to what was once one of the poorest corners of the north.

The village of Bjorenbyr on the downs of western Beinland was founded only two generations ago, as the people of Beinland began to settle inland. It harvests the old-growth forests of the highlands, where great trees might still be found, and are much valued by shipbuilders on the coast and the mainland.

Vostrum was founded by the Calradian mercenary Archacos, one of a number of rogue commanders who broke away from the Empire during its expansion. Unlike some, who tried to reproduce the Empire's republican heritage, he chose to rule as a god-king. His dynasty lasted for generations, until imperial troops overran it and smashed every haloed statue of Archacos and his successors into rubble. Even today, western and northern imperial senators accuse families from this region of being closet monarchists.

Amprela is the foremost town of the northeastern Empire. Watchmen stand atop its towers, looking out for beacons from the frontier fortresses to the north and east that might signal the approach of enemies. Horse archers recruited from the rough Eleftheroi freemen drink in the barracks, waiting for the order to ride out against Khuzait steppe-riders, Sturgian woodsmen or Nord longships coming down the Caracasos River, while the cataphracts drill in the courtyard of the keep and ensure their horses are in fighting trim should the archon need to assemble an army to deal with any larger threat.

Nordic tribes pushing into the dark forests to their east founded the citadel of Hargard several generations ago. It overlooks the river that the Nords call the Jumne, probably a derivation of a Sturgian term for the mysterious burial pits found along its banks. Today, the river forms the main artery of transportation for the Nord kingdom's eastern domains, a meeting-place of Nords, Vakken, Sturgians, and even some forest-dwelling cousins of the steppe tribes, all harvesting the wealth of the river-valley to sell to the peoples of the south.

Hvalvik is the main port on the remote northern island known to the Nords as Beinland, the land of bones. It is debated whether the island's namesake comes from the walrus ivory that drew hunters here, or the only trace that many left behind, buried in shallow graves alongside its bleak gravel-covered shores. In the last few generations, however, a run of milder winters and a growing mainland population has encouraged colonists to seek their fortune in Beinland, and the former cluster of whalers' huts known as Hvalvik is now a thriving town.

Montos sits near the headwaters of the Aminys River, close to the Battanian frontier. The farmers here keep a watchful eye when tending their hillside fields, always looking for raiding parties coming westward from the valley of the Miron River to their east.
